item.title: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:46, topic:362546”]There is no reason. Maybe the original programmers thought sending them in “one go” would make a difference, but it doesn’t, other than the possibility that the client would receive the packets at a later time. Yes, you have the ability to remove packets, but I can’t think of a reason why this would be useful.

CodeForFame, your argument with Davidi2 was because of a misunderstanding on his behalf, and you didn’t help matters either by assuming MINA didn’t queue the packets internally. Why would you want to continue your pointless argument?[/quote]

Classic was always about being available, especially to people with terrible connections, and computers; I originally played on a PII with 256MB or 512MB of RAM (I upgraded around the time that I started playing, I don’t remember if it was before or after), and had a dial-up connection. I know for sure other people had worse computers…

Anyway, removing outdated packets would help both of those, and I don’t see why you would want to make the game unavailable to some people…

As for continuing with Davidi2, it’s purely because he refuses to admit he made a mistake, and thinks he’s right in every sense. Also, I clarified and admitted to not knowing that MINA guaranteed ordering, but that still doesn’t make my initial statement wrong, like he’s trying to make it out to be.

BTW congrats on mod Davidi2, don’t go abusing it now…

Read full topic
item.source: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?

item.title: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

There is no reason. Maybe the original programmers thought sending them in “one go” would make a difference, but it doesn’t, other than the possibility that the client would receive the packets at a later time. Yes, you have the ability to remove packets, but I can’t think of a reason why this would be useful.

CodeForFame, your argument with Davidi2 was because of a misunderstanding on his behalf, and you didn’t help matters either by assuming MINA didn’t queue the packets internally. Why would you want to continue your pointless argument?

Read full topic

item.source: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?

item.title: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Again, I was referring to the stream sending to the client (not writing data into the buffer), and that’s what I was talking about the entire time. Also I’d like to point out you saying: [quote=“CodeForFame, post:31, topic:362546”]You’re now talking about writing to a stream that is using a protocol that guarantees delivery order… The underlying protocol has absolutely nothing to do with if it is asynchronous or synchronous, and that is what ultimately guarantees delivery order.[/quote]Here you recognize what I am talking about, but you change the subject back to asycn vs synch IO, which I think we both agree does not determine order (as we’ve both said it multiple times)…

I still stand by what I said in regards to sending data, which is what you keep quoting.
I also don’t understand why you keep only giving parts of my quotes, for example that first quote you say supports ordering is clearly saying that asynchronous IO does not modify the information at all, which means that while it doesn’t ‘disorder’ the data on purpose, it also doesn’t order it or do anything else.

At the third quote, I did not say “Sending something asynchronously doesn’t guarantee ordering…”, and you’re being a hypocrite by putting words into my mouth as well. If you read on (again you only included part of the quote), I continue to talk about the stream itself, which supports my point that I’m talking about after the data is written into stream, and is being sent to the client. You even recognize this (view the quote at the top of this post) but now you change your mind and say it has to do with asynch IO…?

When are you going to get over yourself and realize we are both right about the ordering of the data when talking about asynch vs synch, but I was just talking about something else when talking about writing to a stream (because again that’s what I interpreted your first post to be about)? This entire thing has been blown way out of proportion :rolleyes:

EDIT - I’m done here, you obviously can’t handle anyone else possibly being right about anything (even if they admit you are right too…) so I’ll step down before this goes on for eternity.

Read full topic
item.source: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?

item.title: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:40, topic:362546”][quote]Continually correcting your misunderstandings is ridiculous, because you’re so dense, and don’t even understand what’s being said… [/quote] It’s funny because I’ve said almost this exactly thing about you because this discussion has jumped around so much…

Note a lot of the time we WERE talking about different things, I was talking about once you’ve written to the stream, the things are sent to the client in the exact same order as you wrote them, which is why I said it guarantees order just like normal IO (hence why I even mentioned the flip method). I assumed you were saying that things are sometimes sent to the client in a different order than they were in the buffer when the send method was called (to be honest I still don’t know what you were/are talking about, because you change the discussion so much…) because yes, that is completely wrong unless you are sending datagram packets. If you care to explain what you WERE talking about, perhaps we can have a civilized discussion. I don’t know why you insist on calling me a moron or idiot because we obviously have a failure of communication and interpretation, but I’ll try not to do the same.

As for the contradictory statements, they all say the same thing except the middle one, which I explained in the paragraph above.

Enjoy.[/quote]

You’ve been the one attempting to change the discussion completely, because you’re talking out of your ass, and pretending I’m saying things I’m clearly not.

No, a lot of the time you were talking about different things, I continually corralled to back to the actual point.

Okay, let’ pretend you were talking about once you’ve written to the stream. You’ve no moved away from what asynchronous IO is, and to the protocol being used. And in that case you’re still wrong, because not every protocol guarantees order. Also, blocking IO makes no guarantees as to the ordering…

I’ve never said that, except when talking about protocols that don’t guarantee ordering… I’ve already explain what I originally said, go back and read. Now, even if I did say that sending things asynchronously doesn’t guarantee ordering I would be correct; thus your initial theory that I didn’t know what asynchronous meant would still have no basis.

You’re assuming that the transport-layer protocol guarantees delivery order, asynchonous IO says absolutely nothing about the protocol that needs to be used… You’re just make irrelevant, and retarded assumptions to make it seem like you’re correct, when you’re fundamentally wrong. Also, there are more transport-layer protocols that don’t have guaranteed delivery order than ones that do.

If you care to actually read what I’ve said you’d notice I’ve already explained it.

You’re the idiot because you’re consistently changing your position, and failing to understand what is being said.

No, they switch pretty much every time…

This one is implying that it guarantees ordering.

Davidi2:

… It does not at all modify, ‘jumble’, mutate, disorder, or whatever else you were saying to the data …

This one is explicitly states that it has nothing to do with ordering.

Davidi2:

Sending things asynchronously has nothing to do with the order…

This one explicitly states that it guarantees ordering. You’re not going to wiggle out of this, you explicitly contradicted, “Sending something asynchronously doesn’t guarantee ordering…”

Davidi2:

No, it does guarantee ordering…

This one explicitly states that you’ve never said asynchronous IO guarantees ordering.

Davidi2:

Never did I say ‘asynchronous io’ provided order

This one is explicitly states that it has nothing to do with ordering.

Davidi2:

… I was the one saying sending things asynchronously had nothing to do with changing the order they are sent in…

As you can see when I explicitly point it out, you’ve said it guarantees ordering twice, and has nothing to do with ordering three times.

On the other hand, I’ve said in all seven posts (regarding this specifically) that it has nothing to do with order. Not once did I contradict myself; though I’ll admit the first post wasn’t very clear, but I made it abundantly clear after that.

Read full topic

item.title: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Continually correcting your misunderstandings is ridiculous, because you're so dense, and don't even understand what's being said...
It's funny because I've said almost this exactly thing about you because this discussion has jumped around so much... :P

Note a lot of the time we WERE talking about different things, I was talking about once you’ve written to the stream, the things are sent to the client in the exact same order as you wrote them, which is why I said it guarantees order just like normal IO (hence why I even mentioned the flip method). I assumed you were saying that things are sometimes sent to the client in a different order than they were in the buffer when the send method was called (to be honest I still don’t know what you were/are talking about, because you change the discussion so much…) because yes, that is completely wrong unless you are sending datagram packets. If you care to explain what you WERE talking about, perhaps we can have a civilized discussion. I don’t know why you insist on calling me a moron or idiot because we obviously have a failure of communication and interpretation, but I’ll try not to do the same.

As for the contradictory statements, they all say the same thing except the middle one, which I explained in the paragraph above.

Enjoy.

Read full topic
item.source: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?

item.title: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

Davidi2:

Considering I was the one saying sending things asynchronously had nothing to do with changing the order they are sent in, I’m confused why you’re saying that (and again, for the same reasons that regular non blocking IO wouldn’t send in order [different threads writing at different times], MINA would have the same problem. So don’t know what you’re talking about there either. :P)

Wow, you really are stupid… I’ve never claimed that doing something asynchronously has anything to do with order, in fact I’ve stated the opposite throughout this entire discussion (asynchronous IO guarantees nothing in regards to ordering, and if you want that guarantee, you need make it yourself, or use a library that does it for you (along with a protocol that guarantees ordering)). On the other hand, you have explicitly stated that it does guarantee ordering, but now you’re switching sides again…

[quote=“Davidi2, post:30, topic:362546”]No, it does guarantee ordering, just like normal IO. It’s a stream (or channel) that things are written to, and they are sent in a specific order and received in the same order. If this was not true then all IO would be very pointless (imagine mixing up the bytes for a split up int, your integer would be completely off)

If you write to a stream in one order, it’s going to send them in that order (or backwards if you use flip() on the buffer)

This is what I was talking about, (and the people that called you ‘a moron’) when I said look up the meaning of asynch IO.[/quote]
Anyway, you’ve been arguing this whole time against things I’ve never even come close to saying, because you clearly don’t know how to read/comprehend English. You’ve also contradicted yourself about the very core of the discussion…

Continually correcting your misunderstandings is ridiculous, because you’re so dense, and don’t even understand what’s being said… Simply put, you’re a complete and utter idiot; you need to figure out what we’re even talking about, go over both of our posts, and then reply. Seeing you have such major issues, I suggest you read it out loud, because it seems to help morons like yourself.

I’ll just end this with a handful of your contradictory statements…

Davidi2:

… It does not at all modify, ‘jumble’, mutate, disorder, or whatever else you were saying to the data …

Davidi2:

Sending things asynchronously has nothing to do with the order…

Davidi2:

No, it does guarantee ordering…

Davidi2:

Never did I say ‘asynchronous io’ provided order

Davidi2:

… I was the one saying sending things asynchronously had nothing to do with changing the order they are sent in…

Read full topic

So don’t know what you’re talking about there either. :P)

item.title: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I think both of you know what you are talking about, but are talking about different things. CodeForFame is correct in saying that since the calls don’t block (are asynchronous), if multiple threads are sending packets, you can’t really guarantee which gets sent first. Davidi2 is correct in saying that the word asynchronous doesn’t mean that things are sent out of order.

[quote=“Not_a_bot, post:24, topic:362546”]It’s using an ArrayList because it has to access any element in the list when sending the packets…it does NOT utilize FIFO. If you were to use LinkedList, you would get thrown exceptions left and right (ConcurrentModification to be exact) since it would not be synchronized with the thread sending them.

[quote=API]
This exception may be thrown by methods that have detected concurrent modification of an object when such modification is not permissible.
[/quote][/quote]

None of what you said makes any sense at all. ArrayList is not synchronized and can throw a concurrent modification exception as well, if it really needs to be synchronized it should be declared like this:

List list = Collections.synchronizedList(new ArrayList(…));
(as stated here: http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/ArrayList.html)

And if it’s not obvious enough, that could just as easily be anything that implements the List interface, even:

List list = Collections.synchronizedList(new LinkedList(…));

Read full topic
item.source: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?

item.title: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

I’m pretty sure we were talking about TCP here, because nobody mentioned UDP as it’s an entirely different protocol that yes, can send things in a different order. Never did I say ‘asynchronous io’ provided order, I’m saying that this server (ie what we are talking about here) does guarantee order because it uses TCP.

Whereas you on the other hand are saying:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:16, topic:362546”]The order in which they’re sent doesn’t matter, nor does it impact anything, because they’re being sent asynchronously (and the order can be mixed up anyway)…[/quote]Which would only be correct if we were using UDP (in which case being sent asynchronously would STILL have nothing to do with the order…).

And funny you should say that, because I’m actually writing a RPG right now that has nothing to do with RSPS.

Read full topic
item.source: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?

item.title: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:30, topic:362546”]No, it does guarantee ordering, just like normal IO. It’s a stream (or channel) that things are written to, and they are sent in a specific order and received in the same order. If this was not true then all IO would be very pointless (imagine mixing up the bytes for a split up int, your integer would be completely off)

If you write to a stream in one order, it’s going to send them in that order (or backwards if you use flip() on the buffer)

This is what I was talking about, (and the people that called you ‘a moron’) when I said look up the meaning of asynch IO.[/quote]

sigh

TCP guarantees ordering, MINA guarantees ordering, but asynchronous anything does not have anything to do with ordering.

If you’re using the UDP asynchronously then you can receive packets out of order. This shows that because something is asynchronous, it doesn’t not guarantee the order ‘sent’ is the order received. Also, if you look closely, you’ll recognize that when using TCP you don’t have to worry about the protocol level out-of-ordering, but you do need to worry about out-of-ordering at the point of writing to the socket on the OS level; there are tons of libraries that abstract this away, including the Java API, and MINA (much further than the Java API).

You’re now talking about writing to a stream that is using a protocol that guarantees delivery order… The underlying protocol has absolutely nothing to do with if it is asynchronous or synchronous, and that is what ultimately guarantees delivery order.

You and the other people who called me a ‘moron’ are obviously oblivious to what asynchronous means, and protocols that don’t guarantee delivery order… You should really come out of the ‘RSPS’ bubble, and learn something useful.

Read full topic
item.source: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?

item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

No, it does guarantee ordering, just like normal IO. It’s a stream (or channel) that things are written to, and they are sent in a specific order and received in the same order. If this was not true then all IO would be very pointless (imagine mixing up the bytes for a split up int, your integer would be completely off)

If you write to a stream in one order, it’s going to send them in that order (or backwards if you use flip() on the buffer)

This is what I was talking about, (and the people that called you ‘a moron’) when I said look up the meaning of asynch IO.

item.source: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?

item.title: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:28, topic:362546”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=458834.msg3637657#msg3637657 date=1308708701]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=458834.msg3637631#msg3637631 date=1308705398]

I do not believe anyone said which was more beneficial, we were just giving options. But you of course, on your high horse, immediately took it upon yourself to demean anyone that said anything contrary to what you believe without even considering if what you interpret as what they say is correct. Not to mention you say something completely incorrect while doing it…

You’ve got to be kidding me… You’re the one that said I was wrong, when you were completely wrong; using a queue in this situation isn’t ‘great’. Using a queue in this situation has no benefits (that I can think of), and you acted as if they were better than using an ArrayList, even though I didn’t even say it was better at that point.

Furthermore, what exactly did I say that was incorrect?
[/quote]I was talking about how you explained Asynchronous IO. It does not at all modify, ‘jumble’, mutate, disorder, or whatever else you were saying to the data (including MINA), all it means is that you can read and write while still performing other tasks without creating new threads for each IO stream. You usually pair blocking and non blocking IO together, usually you have your selector block (Selector.select() instead of Selector.selectNow()) while it waits for new data and then each channel is non-blocking.

I never even came remotely close to saying it modified, jumbled, or mutated anything. I simply said that sending things asynchronously doesn’t guarantee the order in which packets are sent… Now, MINA does guarantee ordering, but it took me a bit of searching to find that out… Apparently, MINA also guarantees that a once a connection is established, only one thread will process the queue for a client.
[/quote]Sending things asynchronously has nothing to do with the order things are sent in… it’s not just MINA.[/quote]

That’s exactly my point… Sending something asynchronously doesn’t guarantee ordering…

Read full topic

It does not at all modify, ‘jumble’, mutate, disorder, or whatever else you were saying to the data (including MINA), all it means is that you can read and write while still performing other tasks without creating new threads for each IO stream. You usually pair blocking and non blocking IO together, usually you have your selector block (Selector.select() instead of Selector.selectNow()) while it waits for new data and then each channel is non-blocking.

I never even came remotely close to saying it modified, jumbled, or mutated anything. I simply said that sending things asynchronously doesn’t guarantee the order in which packets are sent… Now, MINA does guarantee ordering, but it took me a bit of searching to find that out… Apparently, MINA also guarantees that a once a connection is established, only one thread will process the queue for a client.[/quote]Sending things asynchronously has nothing to do with the order things are sent in… it’s not just MINA.

item.title: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:26, topic:362546”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=458834.msg3637584#msg3637584 date=1308701596]

I do not believe anyone said which was more beneficial, we were just giving options. But you of course, on your high horse, immediately took it upon yourself to demean anyone that said anything contrary to what you believe without even considering if what you interpret as what they say is correct. Not to mention you say something completely incorrect while doing it…

You’ve got to be kidding me… You’re the one that said I was wrong, when you were completely wrong; using a queue in this situation isn’t ‘great’. Using a queue in this situation has no benefits (that I can think of), and you acted as if they were better than using an ArrayList, even though I didn’t even say it was better at that point.

Furthermore, what exactly did I say that was incorrect?
[/quote]I was talking about how you explained Asynchronous IO. It does not at all modify, ‘jumble’, mutate, disorder, or whatever else you were saying to the data (including MINA), all it means is that you can read and write while still performing other tasks without creating new threads for each IO stream. You usually pair blocking and non blocking IO together, usually you have your selector block (Selector.select() instead of Selector.selectNow()) while it waits for new data and then each channel is non-blocking.[/quote]

I never even came remotely close to saying it modified, jumbled, or mutated anything. I simply said that sending things asynchronously doesn’t guarantee the order in which packets are sent… Now, MINA does guarantee ordering, but it took me a bit of searching to find that out… Apparently, MINA also guarantees that a once a connection is established, only one thread will process the queue for a client.

[quote=“Not_a_bot, post:24, topic:362546”]It’s using an ArrayList because it has to access any element in the list when sending the packets…it does NOT utilize FIFO. If you were to use LinkedList, you would get thrown exceptions left and right (ConcurrentModification to be exact) since it would not be synchronized with the thread sending them.

API:

This exception may be thrown by methods that have detected concurrent modification of an object when such modification is not permissible.

The method I posted is found in the RSCConnectionHandler class, from what it looks like it’s processed before being sent to the main queue …

Taken from the RSCA source.

[code]public void messageReceived(IoSession session, Object message) {
Player player = (Player) session.getAttachment();
if (session.isClosing() || player.destroyed()) {
return;
}
RSCPacket p = (RSCPacket) message;

/* if(p.getID() == 57 || p.getID() == 73 || p.getID() == 40 || p.getID()
 == 51 || p.getID() == 128 || p.getID() == 206 || p.getID() == 71 ||
 p.getID() == 55)*/

if(p.getID() == 55)
    player.addInterval();

player.addPacket(p);
packets.add(p); 
}[/code]

[code]

public void addPacket(RSCPacket p) {
long now = System.currentTimeMillis();
if (now - lastCount > 3000) {
lastCount = now;
packetCount = 0;
}
if (!DataConversions.inArray(Formulae.safePacketIDs, p.getID())
&& packetCount++ >= 60) {
destroy(false);
}
if (lastPackets.size() >= 60) {
lastPackets.remove();
}
lastPackets.addLast§;
}[/code][/quote]

In the version I have, lastPackets is a LinkedList, and isn’t used for anything but ‘bot detection’…

Anyway, you should be looking at the PacketQueue class for incoming packets. It uses an ArrayList there, and has access synchronized.

Read full topic
item.source: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?

item.title: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:23, topic:362546”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=458834.msg3637541#msg3637541 date=1308699211]
I do not believe anyone said which was more beneficial, we were just giving options. But you of course, on your high horse, immediately took it upon yourself to demean anyone that said anything contrary to what you believe without even considering if what you interpret as what they say is correct. Not to mention you say something completely incorrect while doing it…
[/quote]

You’ve got to be kidding me… You’re the one that said I was wrong, when you were completely wrong; using a queue in this situation isn’t ‘great’. Using a queue in this situation has no benefits (that I can think of), and you acted as if they were better than using an ArrayList, even though I didn’t even say it was better at that point.

Furthermore, what exactly did I say that was incorrect?[/quote]I was talking about how you explained Asynchronous IO. It does not at all modify, ‘jumble’, mutate, disorder, or whatever else you were saying to the data (including MINA), all it means is that you can read and write while still performing other tasks without creating new threads for each IO stream. You usually pair blocking and non blocking IO together, usually you have your selector block (Selector.select() instead of Selector.selectNow()) while it waits for new data and then each channel is non-blocking.

Read full topic
item.source: Does anyone know why RSCD queues outgoing packages?
